verses.text: He made the altar of burnt offering out of acacia wood. It was square, five cubits long and five cubits wide, and three cubits high.
verses.comment: Matching the measurements from Ex. 27:1; a cubit is about 18 inches (45 cm).

verses.text: He made horns for it on its four corners. Its horns were of one piece with it, and he overlaid it with bronze.
verses.comment: As described in the original command; 'of one piece with it' means the horns were part of the main structure.

verses.text: He made all the utensils of the altar, the pots, the shovels, the basins, the forks, and the firepans. He made all its utensils out of bronze.
verses.comment: Tools listed as in the original text; these were used in sacrifice rituals.

verses.text: He made for the altar a grate, a network of bronze, under its rim, reaching halfway up from the bottom.
verses.comment: The bronze grate allowed ashes to fall through; 'under its rim' means below the upper edge.

verses.text: He cast four rings for the four corners of the bronze grate, as holders for the poles.
verses.comment: These rings allowed the altar to be carried as commanded.

verses.text: He made the poles of acacia wood and overlaid them with bronze.
verses.comment: Materials chosen for durability, reflecting original instructions.

verses.text: He inserted the poles into the rings on the sides of the altar, to carry it. He made it hollow, with boards.
verses.comment: 'Hollow, with boards' means it was a frame, not solid throughout.

verses.text: He made the basin of bronze, and its stand of bronze, from the mirrors of the women who served at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
verses.comment: The women's polished bronze mirrors were used, indicating their contribution.

verses.text: He made the courtyard. For the south side the hangings of the courtyard were of fine twisted linen, one hundred cubits long.
verses.comment: Describes the linen curtains surrounding the tabernacle camp.

verses.text: Its twenty pillars and their twenty bronze bases. The hooks of the pillars and their bands were of silver.
verses.comment: Details of construction as previously commanded.

verses.text: For the north side, there were hangings one hundred cubits long, their twenty pillars, and their twenty bronze bases. The hooks of the pillars and their bands were of silver.
verses.comment: Parallels the south side's construction.

verses.text: For the west side, there were hangings fifty cubits long, with their ten pillars and their ten bases. The hooks of the pillars and their bands were of silver.
verses.comment: West side was shorter as per the tabernacle shape.

verses.text: For the east side toward the sunrise, the hangings were also fifty cubits long.
verses.comment: East (entrance) side; matching west side's length.

verses.text: The hangings for one side of the gate were fifteen cubits, with their three pillars and their three bases.
verses.comment: Entrance curtains described by side and measurements.

verses.text: And on the other side, on each side of the court gate, were hangings of fifteen cubits, with their three pillars and their three bases.
verses.comment: Mirror-image of the previous verse for the opposite side.

verses.text: All the hangings around the courtyard were of fine twisted linen.
verses.comment: Materials noted to match the prescribed specifications.

verses.text: The bases for the pillars were of bronze, but the hooks of the pillars and their bands were of silver. The tops of their shafts were overlaid with silver, and all the pillars of the courtyard had silver bands.
verses.comment: 'Bands' refers here to rods or connecting strips of silver.

verses.text: The screen for the gate of the courtyard was embroidered, blue, purple, and scarlet yarns, and fine twisted linen. It was twenty cubits long and five cubits high, corresponding to the hangings of the courtyard.
verses.comment: Reflects the detailed craftsmanship prescribed.

verses.text: Their four pillars and their four bases were bronze, their hooks of silver, and their tops overlaid with silver.
verses.comment: Describes the features of the courtyard gate supports.

verses.text: All the pegs for the tabernacle and around the courtyard were of bronze.
verses.comment: Tent pegs were bronze for durability.

verses.text: This is the inventory of the tabernacle, the tabernacle of the covenant, as recorded at Moses’ command, for the service of the Levites by the hand of Ithamar son of Aaron the priest.
verses.comment: Shifts to a summary of materials; 'covenant' translates 'Testimony.'

verses.text: Bezalel the son of Uri, son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah, made all that the LORD commanded Moses.
verses.comment: 'LORD' uses the traditional replacement for YHWH.

verses.text: And with him was Oholiab, the son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan, an engraver, designer, and embroiderer in blue, purple, and scarlet yarns, and in fine linen.
verses.comment: Lists Oholiab's skills and contribution.

verses.text: All the gold that was used for the work, in all the work of the sanctuary, the gold from the wave offering, was twenty-nine talents and 730 shekels, by the sanctuary shekel.
verses.comment: 'Talents' and 'shekels' are ancient units of weight; a talent is about 75 pounds (34 kg), a shekel about 11 grams.

verses.text: The silver from those of the community who were registered was one hundred talents and 1,775 shekels, by the sanctuary shekel.
verses.comment: 'Registered' refers to the census for the tabernacle tax.

verses.text: A beka per head (that is, half a shekel by the sanctuary shekel), for everyone who passed over to those counted, from twenty years old and upward, for 603,550 men.
verses.comment: A 'beka' is half a shekel, applying to all adult males.

verses.text: The hundred talents of silver were used for casting the bases of the sanctuary and the veil; one hundred bases from the hundred talents, one talent per base.
verses.comment: Each base's weight is specified.

verses.text: And from the 1,775 shekels, he made hooks for the pillars, overlaid their tops, and made bands for them.
verses.comment: Describes other uses for the silver offering.

verses.text: The bronze that was offered was seventy talents and 2,400 shekels.
verses.comment: 'Offered' indicates these were freely given materials.

verses.text: With it he made the bases for the entrance of the tent of meeting, the bronze altar and its bronze grate and all the utensils of the altar,
verses.comment: Bronze was used for structural and functional elements.

verses.text: the bases around the courtyard, the bases for the gate of the courtyard, all the pegs for the tabernacle, and all the pegs around the courtyard.
verses.comment: Finishes listing uses for the bronze; 'pegs' refers to tent pegs.
